newsitem.title: USA: U.S. jobless claims drop hint tight labor markets.
newsitem.headline: U.S. jobless claims drop hint tight labor markets.

text.p: A drop in jobless claims data for the week ended November 2 suggests the U.S. labor markets remain tight, bolstering the theory that consumption in the fourth quarter might be strong, analysts said.

"It indicates that we have a persistent tighteness in the labor market and that should continue indefinitely since we're likely to get a bit stronger consumer numbers in the fourth quarter," said Lee Youngdahl, vice president and an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston and Co Inc.
Youngdahl said the fact that claims are still hovering around current levels means that "there is still hiring going on in the economy."

The Labor Department said jobless claims fell to 331,000 in the week ended November 2 against 342,000 in the previous week. The four-week moving average rose to 333,500 in the week from 331,250 in the last seven-day period.
Analysts said the numbers were not likely to change anyone's ideas about the overall economy.
"That four week moving average has been holding right around 330,000 for a while now," said Greg Jones, economist at Briefing.com, in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
"I think we have to realize that small moves in claims in the range of 10,000 to 20,000 really are not very helpful in predicting job growth," he added.
Analysts said the drop in the figures suggest that some workers who were laid off as a result of a recent General Motors strike did not file for jobless claims.

The GM strike in Canada forced some plants in the U.S. to shut down due to a lack of parts. Pundits did not discount the possibility of a rise in claims over the next few weeks due to the strike effects.
"It could be that these numbers will show up in the next week or two. In any case I think we know that's going to be a short-lived situation anyway," Youngdahl said.

The U.S. money market practically shrugged off the release of the jobless claims data. Analysts said players were more focused on the upcoming auction of $10.0 billion in 30-year Treasury bonds later on Thursday.
"Jobless claims had almost no impact on trading today," said a trader at a U.S. investment bank.
The 6-3/4 percent benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury bond was quoted down 13/32 at 101-10/32 to yield 6.65 percent.
The drop in bonds is mostly tied to an overnight slump in the dollar, trigerred by bearish comments by a Japanese Finance Minister official.
The official, Eisuke Sakakibara, was quoted overnight in a newspaper as saying that the dollar's recovery against the yen from its sharp slide last year was about to finish.
